title: 115_hr6103
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission of the Federal Response to Natural Disasters in Puerto Rico Act of 2018" and its purpose is to establish a commission. The National Commission of the Federal Response to Natural Disasters in Puerto Rico is established to examine the Federal preparedness, response, and recovery to the 2017 natural disasters in Puerto Rico, including activities before, during, and after Hurricanes Irma and Maria. The National Commission is examining Federal efforts to obtain accurate accounting of the death toll, damage impacts, and long-term rebuilding assistance for survivors of Hurricane Maria. The National Commission is examining Federal efforts related to Hurricane Maria, including considerations outlined in Section 3. The Commission will assess Federal response efforts in Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria, comparing them to other impacted areas. Key issues include the impact of the hurricanes, death toll methodology, emergency plans, preparedness guidelines, and the economic vulnerability of Puerto Rico. The Commission will assess Federal response efforts in Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria, focusing on key issues such as the reliance on imported oil for power generation, adequacy of the telecommunications network, capacity for quick mobilization, impact of uncertainty in Federal health care funding, treatment under the Internal Revenue Code, data availability, and geographic/ecological factors affecting response efforts. The Commission will assess Federal response efforts in Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria, focusing on key issues such as reliance on imported oil for power generation, adequacy of the telecommunications network, capacity for quick mobilization, impact of uncertainty in Federal health care funding, treatment under the Internal Revenue Code, data availability, and geographic/ecological factors affecting response efforts. A comparison of response efforts in other United States jurisdictions vis-a-vis efforts in Puerto Rico for the 2017 hurricane season. SEC. 4. COMPOSITION AND COMPENSATION OF COMMISSION. The Commission consists of 8 members appointed by various leaders, who will then choose a Chair and Vice Chair. Members must have expertise in disaster response and emergency preparedness, and cannot be current government officials. The Commission consists of 8 members appointed by various leaders with expertise in disaster response and emergency preparedness. Members are appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment, vacancies are filled within 60 days, and members may be compensated for travel expenses. The President cannot terminate appointments. The Commission can recruit personnel, including private citizens, federal employees, or territorial government employees, with a majority vote. Personnel may assist with the Commission's work and report creation, with expenses allowed similar to intermittent government employees under section 5703 of title 5, United States Code. The Commission has functions and powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission, after all members are appointed, must meet within 60 days to begin operations. Subsequent meetings can be called by the Chair or a majority of members, with a majority constituting a quorum. The Commission must hold at least 10 public meetings in accessible locations and allow written input from participants. The Commission allows written input from participants in Puerto Rico and the mainland for inclusion in the final report. They may hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. The Commission can issue subpoenas for witnesses and documents related to investigations. The Commission can obtain information directly from government agencies, receive administrative support from the General Services Administration, and receive assistance from other federal agencies. They can also use the postal services like other government departments. SEC. 6. REPORTS OF COMMISSION. The Commission is required to submit a final report to the President and Congress within 12 months of the Act's enactment, focusing on the causes and circumstances of natural disasters in Puerto Rico. The report will include recommendations to prevent future disasters outside the continental United States, be available in English and Spanish, address issues outlined in section 2, and detail complaints filed with Inspectors General for Federal agencies post-2017 disasters. The Commission will provide details on Federal procurement practices, disaster mitigation protocols, and disaster response processes post-2017 natural disasters. An appendix will include input from participants in Puerto Rico and the mainland. An interim report will be submitted to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Commission will terminate 90 days after the final report is submitted. $3,000,000 is authorized for this Act.
